text: The Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park is part of the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Site. It is a large park with lakes, temperate rainforests and alpine heathland. Cradle Mountain is a jagged dolerite mountain peak. There are sites around the park where the Australian Aborigines lived 10,000 years ago during the last ice age. Tasmania's tallest mountain, Mt. Ossa, above sea level, is in the park. An area of was protected in May 1922 as a scenic reserve, becoming a National Park in 1972. The National Park now covers an area of . There is a walking track, called the Overland Track, between Cradle Mountain and Lake St Clair. ==Related pages== Other National Parks and reserves in the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area are: * Franklin-Gordon Wild Rivers National Park * Hartz Mountains National Park * Mole Creek Karst National Park * Southwest National Park * Walls of Jerusalem National Park * Central Plateau Conservation Area * Devils Gullet State Reserve * South East Mutton Bird Islet * South East Mutton Bird Islet ==Related pages== Other National Parks and reserves in the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area are: * Franklin-Gordon Wild Rivers National Park * Hartz Mountains National Park * Mole Creek Karst National Park * Southwest National Park * Walls of Jerusalem National Park * Central Plateau Conservation Area * Devils Gullet State Reserve * South East Mutton Bird Islet ==References== Category:Protected areas of Tasmania Category:National parks in Australia Category:Tasmanian Wilderness
title: Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park
